fr.reflexe.viewshell.api.config

Interface IConfigResourceEventContext

  • All Superinterfaces:
    IEventContext

    public interface IConfigResourceEventContext
extends IEventContext
    Configuration resource event context for external changes.
    Since:
    1.0
    Author:
    REFLEXE Technologies

      • isComplete

        boolean isComplete()
        Indicates, for created or updated resources, if writing to the resource appears to be complete.

        An incomplete event means that the resource may not be ready, such as a resource being written to over a slow connection or currently locked by another process. A complete event means that the resource contains no data (such as a directory, or a deleted file) or that the resource appears to have a stable size and a stable modification time.

        Returns:
        true if no changes have been detected for the resource during a fraction of a second, or false if continuous changes have been detected for over 2 seconds (or a file is locked by another process). Also returns true for any delete operation or any operation involving a directory entry.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        ready(long, long)

      • ready

        IAsyncTask ready(long maxStallMsec,
                 long maxWaitMsec)
          throws IOException
        Creates a runnable task that can wait up to a specified number of milliseconds for the file-based resource to attain a stable size.

        The task will poll the file size several times per second. If the size does not change, the task will consider the file size to be stable. To take into account poor (or irregular) transfer rates, a stall duration can be specified to defer the assumption of file stability. If the stall duration is less than the polling interval, then the effective stall duration is equal to the polling interval.

        Note: the returned object does not perform any action until IAsyncTask.run() is invoked, either directly or by an Executor or by some other threading construct.

        Parameters:
        maxStallMsec - maximum stall time in milliseconds, where a stall is a period during which the file size is allowed to remain stable without assuming that writing has finished and that the file is stable. Stalls can occur on slow networks or networks with quality-of-service rules that assign different priorities to different data packets.
        maxWaitMsec - maximum wait in milliseconds for target to become stable.
        Returns:
        an immutable task that can be run, and which returns after determining that the file is apparently stable (determined by polling for changes to the file's size, or after the specified timeout elapses (or if the thread is interrupted).
        Throws:
        IOException - if this path does not currently represent a file.
        IllegalArgumentException - if the maximum stall duration exceeds 1 minute, or if the maximum wait duration exceeds 10 minutes.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        Executor.execute(runnable), new Thread(runnable), isComplete()
